Five years ago, Jamal Khashoggi was murdered for speaking truth to power. Today, we honor his legacy and recommit to protecting human rights and press freedom at home and abroad.

I know many feel disillusioned or angry seeing this chaos in Congress around the budget, the seemingly ever-looming threat of a shutdown. I feel the same—we need to reform the way the Senate can move to reflect the urgency of keeping the government open and protecting families.

And let’s be clear—in the Senate, the larger spending bills we need to pass in the next 45 days have ALREADY passed out of Committee with bipartisan support. That’s a strong foundation of work already accomplished, consensus already reached, by both sides of the aisle.

This continuing resolution buys us 45 days to roll up our sleeves and come to a bipartisan agreement on additional items, including vital aid to Ukraine. We cannot abandon Ukraine—abandon their democracy—in the face of unprovoked Russian aggression.

Last night, I voted for a continuing resolution (or CR) that completed the vision of the deal struck between bipartisan leaders in the House and Senate to avoid a government shutdown, including much-needed disaster aid. A CR means the clock is now ticking.

There's a perverse impact on the health of our democracy as fossil fuel money pours into and corrupts our elections and in the decisions of the captured Court, including the decisions to undermine bedrock environmental protections. We need to get dark money OUT of our elections.

All of our rights, our laws—all of the power the people have—flows from the ballot box. That means the issues that we all care about, including climate, are tied directly to the health of our electoral process and the ability for every eligible voter to make their voice heard.

That’s what the Freedom to Vote Act and John Lewis Voting Rights Act aim to do. These bills would rid our elections of dark money, end partisan gerrymandering, and create critical supports to protect our freedom to vote.

We need to answer the systematic dismantling of our fundamental freedom to vote by GOP-controlled state legislatures with strong federal protections that make sure EVERY eligible voter has equal access to the ballot box.

Voter suppressionists are still working state by to gut access to the ballot box—introducing a record 322 restrictive voting laws across the country this year according to @BrennanCenter. We need to answer these attempts to erode access with decisive federal action.

The VRA was landmark federal legislation to prohibit racial discrimination in access to the ballot box, but voter suppressionists are attacking it. In 2013, SCOTUS gutted the preclearance provision to help ensure voters of color didn’t face discriminatory election regulations.
These new state laws are designed to make it harder for targeted groups to vote: low-income and minority communities, college students, and Native Americans.

Across the country, we’re seeing GOP state legislatures hell-bent on eroding our freedom to vote, whether that’s through gerrymandering, removing polling places, restricting mail-in voting, and more. By @BrennanCenter’s count, 322 bills like this were introduced just this year.

In President Johnson’s words: “It is wrong—deadly wrong—to deny any of your fellow Americans the right to vote in this country.” Protecting access to the ballot box for every eligible voter was the aim—and the legacy—of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

According to @BrennanCenter, state legislatures in 45 states have introduced 322 bills to suppress voters in 2023. They’re targeting vote-by-mail and early voting, and trying to consolidate and get rid of polling places. 

We need to pass the Freedom to Vote Act.

The #ECRA is a step forward on the long road toward protecting the freedom to vote, but we still have a long way to go. I’m working to make sure Congress acts to fight voter suppression, end partisan gerrymandering, and get dark money OUT of our elections.

That attack on our freedom to cast a meaningful vote didn’t begin and end on January 6—GOP state legislatures across the country have been working to erode our freedom to vote state by state, bill by bill. This is an unceasing effort to undermine the voice of the people.

Last month, Congress passed and @POTUS signed the Electoral Count Reform Act into law. This bill is critical in clarifying the role of the Vice President in certifying our elections—helping make sure events like the insurrection on January 6, 2021 never happen again.
